conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light from a source, projecting its outline onto a surface. The position and size of a shadow depend on the height of the light source and the angle of the light rays relative to the object.
As the light source moves upward, the angle of the light rays becomes steeper, causing the shadows to move closer to the base of the objects.
When the light source moves upward, the shadows become smaller because the light rays are more vertical and less spread out.
The apple casts a circular shadow. Its shadow is relatively small and close to the object.
The white cloth casts a rectangular shadow. Its shadow is larger and more spread out compared to the apple.
The transparent object casts a faint shadow due to its translucent nature. Its shadow is elongated and diffused.
The chicken leg casts an irregular shadow. Its shadow is elongated and slightly larger than the object itself.
When the light source moves upward, all shadows (A, B, C, and D) will move closer to the base of their respective objects.
When the light source moves upward, all shadows (A, B, C, and D) will shrink in size because the light rays are more vertical, reducing the spread of the shadows.
In the second image, the shadow of the apple (A) has moved closer to the apple and has become smaller.
In the second image, the shadow of the white cloth (B) has moved closer to the cloth and has become smaller.
In the second image, the shadow of the transparent object (C) has moved closer to the transparent object and has become smaller and less diffused.
In the second image, the shadow of the chicken leg (D) has moved closer to the chicken leg and has become smaller.
When the light source moves upward, the positions of shadows A, B, C, and D move closer to the base of their respective objects, and their sizes become smaller.
